1t was not my intention to appear again in
YOUR paper as the advocate of different
measure from that pursued by the Water
ing Committee, as the discussion seemed
likely to assume personal character, pro-
ductive Of neither utility nor amusement to
YOUR readers the subject, however, is an
important one, and think ought to be TEN


peratey discussed. The attempt made in


your last, to impeach my motives, is as des-
ttute of foundation in fact as it is unworthy
of an honorable opponent. / conceive it is
not only the right but the duty of every cit
izen to watch the movements and inspect
the measures of the public's servants: any
attempts to stile investigation argues cor.
ruption, or to browbeat those who under
take it, is usurpation which ought, in eve
ry republic, to be strenuously resisted.
When we reflect that it only belongs to weak
and ignorant minds to affect great acquire
mcnts and spurn instruction upon every sub
icct, would it be arrogance to presume the
respectable individuals who compose our
watering committee, exempt from any fool
ish pride OF this sort? Their attention has
hitherto been eugrossed by other pursuits


and their knowledge of subjects connected
with their several professions may be very

We are panied to learn that the vencr"
able Charles Carroll Of Carrollton, is now
suffering under the sevcrest pain. A gath
ering having made its appearance OIL one OF
his eyes which it is feared will prove fatal
to the sight. We will be joined, we are sure
by every American, in the hope that this
only and honorable remnant of that band OF
worthless that sustained them IN the darkest
hour of our volution, may again be restor-
ed to his family in his former good health.

CORFU, May 20.


(Priyatc correspondence. )--'The expedition
Of Ibrahim Pacha into the interior of the Pelo-
ponessls appears destined to exterminate every
living being who remains there Ii is species
ofchase, in which he surrounds every village,
one after the other. lie then introduces num-
bcr Of Arabian horsemen to fulfil the functions
Of greyhounds, in order that no ono nay escape
his sanguinary hands. This is new way OF
making war, the invention of which belongs to
the Arab Chief The report of these atrocities
having been spread into all the western part Of
Peloponess,is, the old men, women and children,
who had retired to the SUBMITS of the mountains,
descended by hundreds to the shores of the Mo
rea, to mplore the protection of the sailors who
frequent the coast of this once fourshn, coun-
try.

Syra, OF 23d of May, state that Gen. Church had
been able to collect 4G00 men in the rieus,
where he had entrenched himself; he has besides
sent 5000 men to the defles, to intercept tht
supplies of provisions which came 20 the Turk
from Negropont. Lord Cochrane was ready t.
sail from Peros, with the TIcllas frgate, and 9th
ervessels, laden with provisions and ammunition
and had sunk corvette.

Submarine Navigation Some experiments
in submarine navigation have been lately made
on the Seine by NJ. Bca,tdouni, with boat OF
his invention. Ii is said that by the mechanism
of bis boat he can descend to the bottom, and
raise himself again at pleasure. On the 9th ut,
which was his second trial, one hour elapsed
from the time his boat left the surface of the wa
ter, until it reappeared, and he spent AZ min.
utes of that time at the bottom, at depth OF IL
feet.

The New novel of Sir Walter Scott. enc
titled the Chronicles of the Canongate, is in
press and will appear in London early in
October. About the same time, another
work will be issued from the same hands,
which is to be called Tales of a Grandfa-
ther, being series of stories from the his
tory of Scotland, designed for the authors
grandson.


The venerable DR.. Holyoke, says the Sac
lem Gazette, entered on the hundreth year
of his age last Sunday. From the health of
his body and the vigor of his mind, life is
yet blessing to him and to his friends. He
preserves his relish for literature and soci-
ETY.. We occasionally observe him passing
to and from our public library with book
in his hand and few of his juniors devote
more hours to reading. His eyesight is so
good that he reads without spectacles.


Lah.-The bark of the chestnut (Fagus casta-
nea) is said to contain twice as much tan as that
of the oak, and gives, with sulphate of iron,
beautiful black ink. The color that this tan
produces is less liable to change by the sun and
rain than that produced by sumac.

The Life of Napoleon, by Sir Walter Scott,
will be published next week, in three volumes,
by AIessrs. Carey, Lea & C rey. One edition OF
it will be so cheap as to be within the power of
almost every man to purchase, and the finer ed-
ton will be sold on more reasonable terms, per-
haps than any other book Of its Importance and
merit, ever published in this country.

4 steam boiler belonging to an engine in a
dyeing shop in Paris, lately exploded with great
violence and with report said to be equal TO
that Of a So FOUNDER. The boiler was driven
through strong wall, into a ne,ghborng gar-
den; and the fireman was killed, apparently by
the conclusion Of the air; his body exhibiting no
external marks of violence.

or from some New York paper, a statement
that one of the gentlemen engaged in an at
fair Of honor in Rhode Island. had chopped

Extraordinary Births.-A lady, the wife OF
Mr.. John Kelly, now residing in Wolf creek
township, in this county, (Mercer, Penn( re
Gently from Ireland, yesterday had fre living
children at one birth! They all died shortly af-
ter as we are informed by the physician who at
tended her. Previous to her leaving Ireland,
this same lady had t,co at once and on her way,
hither, while in the state of New-York, she had
fve at one brth-making, in all ftcelue children
within about 18 months. All these births were
premature. The lady and her husband ave
healthy, fresh. young looking people, and only
two years married,

The communication Of a"Citizen of Will
mington," has been received. The cordial
invitation which the writer gives to the cit-
zens to attend the theatre, would, were we
to publish it, be rather out of season, as we
have been informed the dramatic corps
closed their performances for'the present,
last evening. We would, by the bye, IN
form our correspondent that we are not in
the habit of admitting writer's to our col
umns "whose style is unexampled in the an
nails of Billings-gate abuse"


A correspondent in Poulson's Ad vertiscr,
states that lie has received a letter from





the Canal, in which he says the Contractors
are making rapid progress in waling the
canal with stone The wall is said to entire
ly arrest the progress of the running sand
near the bottom of the canal. The stones
are brought from Port Deposit in sloops, to
the western point OF the canal. and are then
carried to the places where they are wanted
on the line, in Wagons. Seven vessels and 40
teams Of four horses each. are employed in
bringing and distributing stone. The work
is also said to progress with great facility and
the most sang uine expectations are enter
tanned Of It's early completion.


4 The three pirates. nehe, Couro, and Fe-
liz, who were convicted of having murdered
a great part Of the crew OF the brig Craw-
ford, and sentenced to be hung, were on Fri
day last, pursuant to their sentence, exc
cutcd at Norfolk, in the presence of an i'm
mensc number Of spectators The prison
ers, clad in purple robes. were taken from
the Jail about eleven o'clock, and escorted
by the military to the gallows. when in the
face of the multitude they acknowledged
that they deserved the fate that awaited
them; they asked the forgiveness of the
people, and begged that they would join
in prayer for their salvation. The gal
lows was so constructed that all three
were to be fastened to as many staples
in the horizontal bar above at once; and the
platform, by means Of hinges, was to be sud-
denly removed from under them. The
ropes had been fastened about their necks
before the removal from the jail aud only
required to be fastened to the staples. This
was soon done by the Deputy Marshals, who
descended to withdraw the support, and al
low the platform to sink, and leave them
suspended. Daring the whole Of this ope-
ration, (Which required several minutes, as
all three had to be fastened to the cross bar
at the same t,mc) the prisoners continued tt
pray aloud. When the prop was withdraw
they tell so suddenly, that the ropes by whlcl
Pepe and Couro were suspended, broke
and they fell to the ground. Felix. being
not SO heavy, remained suspended. The 9th
ers were much injured by the fall, and ths
!, pressure of the cords around their necks
They struggled upon the ground for few
seconds, apparently in great pain Pep'
soon osc upon his feet and threw himself il


an attitude of supplcation to Heaven


Couro remained ON the ground. As soon a
possible. the Deputy Marshals had the plat
f form again raised, placing the legs of Fe
! lix (who, by this tine, was deatD upon th'
top OF it, his body remaining still suspended
| Pepe was again conducted up, and ascend
ed the steps with apparent strenth and res
o1ution. Couro had only the appearance o


life, and was carried up. The ropes wer'


again fixcd-Couro was able to stand afte


being upon his feet. Neither spoke. ane
: pepe remained in supplicatins attitude
The prop being again removed, they wer'
{ left suspended, and soon breathcd their last
; For the Wlmingtonian.

Twenty-nine men, women and children.
(says the N. Y. Commercial Advertiser,)
were Yesterday taken from one cellar in
James street, by Mr.. Schurcman, Visitor of
the Aims House, in state of extreme
wretchedness. The corpse of child that
had been dead since Tuesday last was also
found in the same chamber; and the whole
presented spectacle of filth disgusting be-
yond expression. Part of the inmates of the
dwelling were sent to the Penitentiary and
part to the Aims House; and we trust meas
ures will be taken Immediately to remove
the building itself.

communicated to Capt. Hull, in the morning
by Capt. Maig. Capt, Hull Immediately
cleared his ship tor action, double shotted
the guns, hoisred the broad pendant and the
American colours, and said to his chict Off
GERS: IH see if he will fire into me, The
frigate was soon under way, with tomkins
out and matches lighted, and sailed close to
the Castle without receiving shot. But a
boat was sent by Gen. Rodl to Capt Hull,
with an ahology. which he accepted, and
the frigate returned to her former anchoring
ground. No doubt existed in the minds Of
any of the officers of Capt. Hull, that a se-
verc engagement would ensue, if the frigate
was fred upon.-- 1homasftn Reg.


O6acrUationS on the heat ofths Atmoshhere.


1t ltappears from various observations re-
peatcd in the NJ sspapers, that the heat has
been extreme, and even intolerablc in vari-
Gus parts Of the United States, from the 1st
to the 10th Of the present month Of August.
In New York, on the 9th, the thermometer
rose, in the shade, to 98 degrees Of Fahren.
heit, and did not vary much in the night,
and from the 1st to the 9th it had f1uctuated
from Sc to SO at noon, and from 78 to 81 at
night.


This uncommon phenomenon may be at
tributed to the following concurrent causes


1st. To the opposition Of the whole disc
Of the moon, or, in other words, TO the full
ness of that planet, during the above men
toned period.


:. To the more vertical position Of the
sun over the equator during the same peri
od


8. To the moon being in her perigee, that
is several degrees nearer to the earth dur
ing the same period.


As the moon shines with no other light,
but with the radiant matter she reflects
from the sun, and as that from the moon to
the earth, is made sensible not only by the
light it diffuses but by the caloric it con-
tans, attested by optical experiments, and
by its known operative effect on vegetation,
it follows Of course, that more abundant
quantity Of that matter having been reverb
Grated on tho earth at night, aud the rays oil
the sun having fallen almost vertically upon
us, during the same period, it is not to be
wondered if VIC have experienced an un.
common degree of heat in the day, and We
ry little refreshment while the sun illumcd
the other half of our tcrraqueous globe.


At the decline OF the moon, that is, when
the opposition ceases, and when the earth
overshadows the moon, our good citizens
and their amiabe companions may expect
more comfortable days and pleasant nights


NJ X. Courier.

full articles.headline: TUNNELS IN ENGLAND.
full articles.article:
The first tunnel ever constructed in England,
was on the Trent and Mersey Canal, executed
Tor the Duke of Bridgewater 1t is about 1880
yards IN length, and some parts arc cut out of
the solid rock. The canal is 93 miles in length,
and four other tunnels-13l, $50, 574 and 1241
yards.


The Worcester and birmingham Canal, of 90
miles IN length, have S tunnels; one of 2700 yards
long, Is feet high. and 49, feet wide, and four
others-110, 100, 400, and 500 yards long


The Leeds and Liverpool canal has two tun-
hes, one of which is 1850 Yards.
The Leccstershire and Northampton canal
ms four tunnels, s,of275, $50, 800, and 1856 yards.
The l.eominster canal has two tunnels, of 1850
and $3.50 yards.


The Thames and Severn canal has one tunnel
ol $500 yards, or 2 miles and 3-8ths.


The Chesterfield Canal has two tunnels, one
oi Which is 1850 yards in length.


The Crumford canal has one tunnel of c966
Yards, and several smaller.


The Dudley and Owen canal has three tun-
nes, of 623, 1926, and 3776 yards or about four
miles


The Ellesmcre canal has two tunnels, of 4s7
and us yards.


The Hereford and Gloucester canal, of 353
miles, has three, of 440, 1920, and 2l92 yards.
The Edgebarton canal has four tunnels, of
W., 400, 500, and 2700 yard.


fhe old Birmingham canal has two tunnels,
one OF mile and quarter the other one thou
sand yards.


Ihe Grand Union canal has two tunnels, 1l65
and 1924 yards


% Inc Grand Junction canal has two tunnels
'Va5, and 5000 yards.


;, lhe Oxford canal has two tunnels, one Of
Uem 1888 yards.


The Huddersfield canal, of only 191 miles long,
wi,a iockage of 770 feet has a tunnel of 3
miles and 154o yards, through rocky mountain.

full articles.headline: For the Wilnlingtonian.
full articles.article:
1t was not my intention to appear again in
YOUR paper as the advocate of different
measure from that pursued by the Water
ing Committee, as the discussion seemed
likely to assume personal character, pro-
ductive Of neither utility nor amusement to
YOUR readers the subject, however, is an
important one, and think ought to be TEN


peratey discussed. The attempt made in


your last, to impeach my motives, is as des-
ttute of foundation in fact as it is unworthy
of an honorable opponent. / conceive it is
not only the right but the duty of every cit
izen to watch the movements and inspect
the measures of the public's servants: any
attempts to stile investigation argues cor.
ruption, or to browbeat those who under
take it, is usurpation which ought, in eve
ry republic, to be strenuously resisted.
When we reflect that it only belongs to weak
and ignorant minds to affect great acquire
mcnts and spurn instruction upon every sub
icct, would it be arrogance to presume the
respectable individuals who compose our
watering committee, exempt from any fool
ish pride OF this sort? Their attention has
hitherto been eugrossed by other pursuits


and their knowledge of subjects connected
with their several professions may be very

full articles.headline: Fron, Tie .4nuaaohs Carroihonian.
full articles.article:
We are panied to learn that the vencr"
able Charles Carroll Of Carrollton, is now
suffering under the sevcrest pain. A gath
ering having made its appearance OIL one OF
his eyes which it is feared will prove fatal
to the sight. We will be joined, we are sure
by every American, in the hope that this
only and honorable remnant of that band OF
worthless that sustained them IN the darkest
hour of our volution, may again be restor-
ed to his family in his former good health.

The Noniteur of Monday contains an ordin-
,nce for the rc-estabshment Of the censorship
of the uress, and three other ordinances rcgulat-
;nr all the details of this most obnoxious meas
ure. Every number of each journal or perlod-
cal writing must, before il is printed, be furnish

Censors which shall authorize its publication,
according TO the law of the 3lst March, l890.-

ment

CORFU, May 20.


(Priyatc correspondence. )--'The expedition
Of Ibrahim Pacha into the interior of the Pelo-
ponessls appears destined to exterminate every
living being who remains there Ii is species
ofchase, in which he surrounds every village,
one after the other. lie then introduces num-
bcr Of Arabian horsemen to fulfil the functions
Of greyhounds, in order that no ono nay escape
his sanguinary hands. This is new way OF
making war, the invention of which belongs to
the Arab Chief The report of these atrocities
having been spread into all the western part Of
Peloponess,is, the old men, women and children,
who had retired to the SUBMITS of the mountains,
descended by hundreds to the shores of the Mo
rea, to mplore the protection of the sailors who
frequent the coast of this once fourshn, coun-
try.

considerable--one may be an expert man OF
an excellent Judge of liquors, 8lc.-but when
it is known to be fact that a majority ofthis
committee were persuaded to believe there
was no vafvc between the forcing pump and
the reservoir of the water-works at Phila-
delphia!l is it presumption to suppose them
extremely ignorant of hydraulics? ! men
tion this as no disparagement of their tai


ents, which are confessed clever on general
topics, but to shew the necessity of their a
valling themselves of the aid of others ac-
quainted with the subject, rather than spend
perhaps $1,000 in experiments to acquire a
portion of knowledge that has been common
stock for ages. 1t is also fact well known
to many of our citizens, that several of this
Committee have urged the propriety and ad-
vantage of taking the water, for the pump,
from below the wheel, admitting that we
had the right to take it from the head.
Even P. justified it in his first essay,
which, as he seems to have forg often, will
quote:-"As the pump will only have to lift
the water by atmospheric pressure, about
four feet, can see no serious difficulty in
machinery more complicated or more ex-
pensive;" this is what called arguing for
its expedency, and though in subsequent
essay he says "no mechanic would, for mo-
ment, hesitate to say that the water should
be taken from the head;' and some of the
Committee are willing to concede this much


Yet now It'll contended they are under the
necessity Of acting differently, notwithstand-
ing the opinion of an eminent attorney, en-
Ihloyed since tie purchase. to instruct them


as to the extent Of their rights, or whether
they had any at all. to convert the water to


other purposes than manufacturing -four


He gave them written opinion, in sub


stance, that they were entitled to quanti-


ty Of water from the race, not exceeding


what the mill required, to appropriate to any


purpose they might choose, Qawfui purpose


Of course understood). This quantity is as


cettAined to be about 90 hogsheads per min


ute, under certain head OF water;-the APP


erture that vents it is also now asceitained
, and when the water shall be applied to thu


forcing pump, it will be the right of the mil
lers, and one they will soon exercise if wa
ter is scarce, to demand that the apertur,
shall be limited or defined by the standard


which the mill itself furnishes.


Now, is it not an evident deduction Of reason


that if the Corporation can do what they pleas,
with the portion allowed them, that they ma,
drink part of it if they please, and pour til,


residue on the wheel, or in other words that the,


may take their hogshead per minute for the sup


ply Of the pump, and throw the remaining Is OF
the wheel, or any other distribution Of the modi
cum that experiment may render most advisable
AFTER it has pas s-ed the gate which determines it
AS the advantage Of this application of the we
ter has been discussed and conceded, it will no


be nccdtul to pursue it further at present.


would. however, observe that as the mill is leas
5 dior 900 dollars per annum, subject to deduc
ton Of three dollars for every nychthemeron da
0 the pump is worked, that there will be an add
II tonalitem of expence, ofabout forty cents ,la
il TO be pumped out of the citizens Of the Boroug
;, at the same time, more than would be, by tn
plan advocate, and AS the power of the mill ha
been vastly overrated, this will form no incon
siderable difference in the nett proceeds of tn
J. mill All this, Irepeat it, for purpose wors
y than useless: and such an one as is pronounce
: by many of our intelligent citizens stigma upo
i, our good sense, until it is abandoned. @.

Submarine Navigation Some experiments
in submarine navigation have been lately made
on the Seine by NJ. Bca,tdouni, with boat OF
his invention. Ii is said that by the mechanism
of bis boat he can descend to the bottom, and
raise himself again at pleasure. On the 9th ut,
which was his second trial, one hour elapsed
from the time his boat left the surface of the wa
ter, until it reappeared, and he spent AZ min.
utes of that time at the bottom, at depth OF IL
feet.

1ktalic Cloihes.--At the late exhibition OF the
products of national industry at the Louvre III
Paris, there was exhibited waistcoat, and sew
eral other articles, made of metal wire, which
are said in the report OF the jury appointed to

The New novel of Sir Walter Scott. enc
titled the Chronicles of the Canongate, is in
press and will appear in London early in
October. About the same time, another
work will be issued from the same hands,
which is to be called Tales of a Grandfa-
ther, being series of stories from the his
tory of Scotland, designed for the authors
grandson.


The venerable DR.. Holyoke, says the Sac
lem Gazette, entered on the hundreth year
of his age last Sunday. From the health of
his body and the vigor of his mind, life is
yet blessing to him and to his friends. He
preserves his relish for literature and soci-
ETY.. We occasionally observe him passing
to and from our public library with book
in his hand and few of his juniors devote
more hours to reading. His eyesight is so
good that he reads without spectacles.


Lah.-The bark of the chestnut (Fagus casta-
nea) is said to contain twice as much tan as that
of the oak, and gives, with sulphate of iron,
beautiful black ink. The color that this tan
produces is less liable to change by the sun and
rain than that produced by sumac.

The Life of Napoleon, by Sir Walter Scott,
will be published next week, in three volumes,
by AIessrs. Carey, Lea & C rey. One edition OF
it will be so cheap as to be within the power of
almost every man to purchase, and the finer ed-
ton will be sold on more reasonable terms, per-
haps than any other book Of its Importance and
merit, ever published in this country.

4 steam boiler belonging to an engine in a
dyeing shop in Paris, lately exploded with great
violence and with report said to be equal TO
that Of a So FOUNDER. The boiler was driven
through strong wall, into a ne,ghborng gar-
den; and the fireman was killed, apparently by
the conclusion Of the air; his body exhibiting no
external marks of violence.

a man of fhonor.-The foreigner Of distinc-
tion," who was lately wounded in duel in r. L.,
and who was obliged to remain for some time in
Pawtncket until his wounds should be healed,
has, it seems, ran off without paying his tavern.
bill most droll conception on honor truly!
The Pawtueket Chronicle rcmailss-ssuch is
the duelst. He will fight for honor, be wound
ed for honor, murder for honor; but he will not
pay for honor or justice.-N 4 Times


sore story good mttR il hath IFS ftkory."
We copied from the Pawtucket Chronicle,
or from some New York paper, a statement
that one of the gentlemen engaged in an at
fair Of honor in Rhode Island. had chopped
the twig" from Pawtuckct, without paying
his tavern bill. Since this we have seen the
tavern bill recchted il .fuH far eign days
at four dollars per diem. amounting to
S32 as pretty piece of composition, as to
price, from the circumstances disclosed to
us, "as onc-would wish to see on summers
day." The Pawtucket tavern will not have
much Of duelling, or other custom at that
price, unless he keeps better lardcr, and
stops such advertisements. 10 get wonnd-
ed, pay such bill, and be squibbed in the
newspaper, is as severe as the Connecticut
sentence, that "ihc defendant should be
hanged, and pay forty shillings"

Extraordinary Births.-A lady, the wife OF
Mr.. John Kelly, now residing in Wolf creek
township, in this county, (Mercer, Penn( re
Gently from Ireland, yesterday had fre living
children at one birth! They all died shortly af-
ter as we are informed by the physician who at
tended her. Previous to her leaving Ireland,
this same lady had t,co at once and on her way,
hither, while in the state of New-York, she had
fve at one brth-making, in all ftcelue children
within about 18 months. All these births were
premature. The lady and her husband ave
healthy, fresh. young looking people, and only
two years married,

The communication Of a"Citizen of Will
mington," has been received. The cordial
invitation which the writer gives to the cit-
zens to attend the theatre, would, were we
to publish it, be rather out of season, as we
have been informed the dramatic corps
closed their performances for'the present,
last evening. We would, by the bye, IN
form our correspondent that we are not in
the habit of admitting writer's to our col
umns "whose style is unexampled in the an
nails of Billings-gate abuse"


A correspondent in Poulson's Ad vertiscr,
states that lie has received a letter from





the Canal, in which he says the Contractors
are making rapid progress in waling the
canal with stone The wall is said to entire
ly arrest the progress of the running sand
near the bottom of the canal. The stones
are brought from Port Deposit in sloops, to
the western point OF the canal. and are then
carried to the places where they are wanted
on the line, in Wagons. Seven vessels and 40
teams Of four horses each. are employed in
bringing and distributing stone. The work
is also said to progress with great facility and
the most sang uine expectations are enter
tanned Of It's early completion.


4 The three pirates. nehe, Couro, and Fe-
liz, who were convicted of having murdered
a great part Of the crew OF the brig Craw-
ford, and sentenced to be hung, were on Fri
day last, pursuant to their sentence, exc
cutcd at Norfolk, in the presence of an i'm
mensc number Of spectators The prison
ers, clad in purple robes. were taken from
the Jail about eleven o'clock, and escorted
by the military to the gallows. when in the
face of the multitude they acknowledged
that they deserved the fate that awaited
them; they asked the forgiveness of the
people, and begged that they would join
in prayer for their salvation. The gal
lows was so constructed that all three
were to be fastened to as many staples
in the horizontal bar above at once; and the
platform, by means Of hinges, was to be sud-
denly removed from under them. The
ropes had been fastened about their necks
before the removal from the jail aud only
required to be fastened to the staples. This
was soon done by the Deputy Marshals, who
descended to withdraw the support, and al
low the platform to sink, and leave them
suspended. Daring the whole Of this ope-
ration, (Which required several minutes, as
all three had to be fastened to the cross bar
at the same t,mc) the prisoners continued tt
pray aloud. When the prop was withdraw
they tell so suddenly, that the ropes by whlcl
Pepe and Couro were suspended, broke
and they fell to the ground. Felix. being
not SO heavy, remained suspended. The 9th
ers were much injured by the fall, and ths
!, pressure of the cords around their necks
They struggled upon the ground for few
seconds, apparently in great pain Pep'
soon osc upon his feet and threw himself il


an attitude of supplcation to Heaven


Couro remained ON the ground. As soon a
possible. the Deputy Marshals had the plat
f form again raised, placing the legs of Fe
! lix (who, by this tine, was deatD upon th'
top OF it, his body remaining still suspended
| Pepe was again conducted up, and ascend
ed the steps with apparent strenth and res
o1ution. Couro had only the appearance o


life, and was carried up. The ropes wer'


again fixcd-Couro was able to stand afte


being upon his feet. Neither spoke. ane
: pepe remained in supplicatins attitude
The prop being again removed, they wer'
{ left suspended, and soon breathcd their last
; For the Wlmingtonian.

your paper as the advocate of differcn

has generously advertised to admit four
from each school.

Twenty-nine men, women and children.
(says the N. Y. Commercial Advertiser,)
were Yesterday taken from one cellar in
James street, by Mr.. Schurcman, Visitor of
the Aims House, in state of extreme
wretchedness. The corpse of child that
had been dead since Tuesday last was also
found in the same chamber; and the whole
presented spectacle of filth disgusting be-
yond expression. Part of the inmates of the
dwelling were sent to the Penitentiary and
part to the Aims House; and we trust meas
ures will be taken Immediately to remove
the building itself.

communicated to Capt. Hull, in the morning
by Capt. Maig. Capt, Hull Immediately
cleared his ship tor action, double shotted
the guns, hoisred the broad pendant and the
American colours, and said to his chict Off
GERS: IH see if he will fire into me, The
frigate was soon under way, with tomkins
out and matches lighted, and sailed close to
the Castle without receiving shot. But a
boat was sent by Gen. Rodl to Capt Hull,
with an ahology. which he accepted, and
the frigate returned to her former anchoring
ground. No doubt existed in the minds Of
any of the officers of Capt. Hull, that a se-
verc engagement would ensue, if the frigate
was fred upon.-- 1homasftn Reg.


O6acrUationS on the heat ofths Atmoshhere.


1t ltappears from various observations re-
peatcd in the NJ sspapers, that the heat has
been extreme, and even intolerablc in vari-
Gus parts Of the United States, from the 1st
to the 10th Of the present month Of August.
In New York, on the 9th, the thermometer
rose, in the shade, to 98 degrees Of Fahren.
heit, and did not vary much in the night,
and from the 1st to the 9th it had f1uctuated
from Sc to SO at noon, and from 78 to 81 at
night.


This uncommon phenomenon may be at
tributed to the following concurrent causes


1st. To the opposition Of the whole disc
Of the moon, or, in other words, TO the full
ness of that planet, during the above men
toned period.


:. To the more vertical position Of the
sun over the equator during the same peri
od


8. To the moon being in her perigee, that
is several degrees nearer to the earth dur
ing the same period.


As the moon shines with no other light,
but with the radiant matter she reflects
